The California Public Utilities Commission ordered Pacific Gas & Electric Co. to pay a record $1.6 billion penalty for unsafe operation of its natural gas transmission system. On September 9, 2010, a section of PG&E pipeline exploded in San Bruno, killing eight people and injuring more than 50 others. PG&E said it has already replaced more than 800 miles of pipe, installed new gas leak technology and implemented nine of 12 recommendations from the National Transportation Safety Board.

a Neanderthal. Altamura Man fell into a well about 150,000 years ago. Scientists believe he fell in the well, then died of thirst or hunger. Last month, researchers extracted his DNA from a cave in Italy. They hope to sequence his DNA to learn more about evolution of all hominids -- including us.

According to Guiness World Records, the oldest person ever was Jeanne Louise Calment, who died at age 122 in 1997.

Tickets were set at £23 for the North and South stands, with the East Stand being £15 for adults and £5 for concessions.

They dismissed the call and later found the marsupial in a field in Bruhl, 20 kilometres south of the city centre of Cologne. It is suspected that the animal's fencing was damaged due to severe storms.

Lucy Garrod, 27, developed a corneal abrasion in her right eye. It was caused by bacteria growing underneath her contact lens. Doctors told her she would not be able to complete her photography degree. But after a year in hospital, Miss Garrod learned to use her left eye. They cut a flap in the cornea and used ultrasound to guide laser surgery. This removed the scarred area of her right eye and restored her sight. She passed with first class honours at Bournemouth University.

A video maker captured a freak snowstorm engulfing a bridge and then a river in a matter of seconds in Russia. Flecks of snow can be seen beating down on the side of the river bank as the large cloud grows in size. Visibility is drastically reduced as the storm moves at a speed of 45mph and the Yenisei River disappears from view.
Fritz the Golden Retriever from California appears to lack any eye-mouth co-ordination skills, as a new video shows. Slow-motion footage shows him licking his lips and enthusiastically leaping up to catch a hard-boiled egg between his teeth. However, despite his best efforts, the egg narrowly misses his jaw, bounces off his chest and hits the grass instead.

Researchers at Brown University in Rhode Island tested nine people who play video games. They found that gamers improved their speed and accuracy on both tasks, while non-gamers did worse on the first. The study doesn't prove whether gaming makes people learn skills better - or whether people with an innate ability become gamers.

Excited, the bird runs after it and rolls the ball to the left with its foot. After successfully rolling the ball back, the bird jumps up on it with two feet. A letter from Richie Benaud to an English fan, Jonathon Stevenson, almost 20 years ago emerged on Friday in the wake of the cricket legend's death. The typed letter, dated September 27, 1996, was personally signed by Benaud. It included tips on different deliveries and gave pointers as to how they should be delivered. Benaud enjoyed a remarkable Test career as a wily leg-spin bowler and middle-order batsman which ended with his retirement in 1964. He was the first player to score 2,000 Test runs and take 200 Test wickets.
Cricket commentator Richie Benaud has died aged 84 in a Sydney hospice. He was diagnosed with skin cancer in November and had been receiving radiation treatment for the past two summers. As a player, Benaud became the first player from any nation to score 2000 Test runs and take 200 Test wickets. The Nine Network will air a special on the life of cricketing great Richie Benaud on Saturday night at 7pm.

The video shows a man lying down on his back and kicking his legs in the air to lure a mob of Emus. The Emus - known to be particularly curious birds - come close to see what's going on, then scatter as the guide leapt to his feet. It's thought to be an old Aboriginal trick to catch an emu - who are too fast to catch on foot.

Jeanetta Riley, 35, a Native American woman was killed last July after she brandished a knife at two Idaho police officers. She was taken to hospital by her husband, 44-year-old Shane, following threats she made to kill herself. In surveillance footage, Jeanetta is heard in exchange with officers as they repeatedly tell her to put the knife down but she refuses. Fourteen hours later, a dog called Arfee was fatally shot by police in nearby Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, in a killing.

Neighbors say they were alerted to the bodies by the couple’s 4-year-old girl just after midnight on Saturday. The couple have been named as Georgina Rojas-Medina, 41, and her common-law husband, Gerardo Tovar, 44.
Researchers claim children who share iPads in class do much better in early literacy tests than those who don’t. Courtney Blackwell, from Northwestern University in the US, worked with 352 students at a Midwestern suburban school district during the research. She said the findings suggest it’s the ‘collaborative learning around the technology that made the difference’

Former Australian captain Richie Benaud died aged 84 on Friday. The cricket commentator had been receiving radiation treatment for skin cancer since November when he was admitted to a Sydney hospice on Thursday. He was the first player from any nation to score 2,000 Test runs and take 200 Test wickets but was as much renowned for his captaincy. Shane Warne said: 'As a cricketer, commentator and as a person, you were the best there's ever been'

Australian artist George Gittoes has just been awarded the 2015 Sydney Peace Prize. The 65-year-old was named as the recipient on Saturday in recognition of his 45 years chronicling conflicts around the world. He said it's welcome recognition that 'creativity is the opposite of war, where they're destroying' Mr Gittoes recently visited war-torn Afghanistan, establishing an artist collective in the city of Jalalabad.

The high-wire performer said Monday at a New York City news conference that the Orlando Eye will be moving when he attempts his feat. Wallenda previously walked atop a Ferris wheel in Santa Cruz, California, but he said the size of the much larger Orlando wheel and the fact that he will not use a pole sets this stunt apart.

EmbryoScope technology allows medics to record the microscopic miracle of life from fertilisation to the division of cells, right through to the growth of an embryo. The tiny camera, placed inside an incubator, films the reproduction process from the moment the embryo forms to the birth of Pixie Morley. Experts have hailed the technology as one of the most important developments in IVF.

Bubba Watson has won all four of his majors so far this year, while Tiger Woods could only finish 50th in defence of his title two years ago. Dustin Johnson and Jimmy Walker are the big hitters who have shown they possess the perfect mix of long driving, precise iron control and dead-eyed putting.

YouTuber, MicahMedia, has uploaded a 28-second video showing the simplest and swiftest way to peel a hardboiled egg. He places a hard-boiled egg in a small tumbler glass before it is filled quarter of the way with tap water. After vigorously shaking the glass, he lifts up the shell of the egg which has been loosened from the egg. The video has over 16million views on the video-sharing website.

Cricket commentator Richie Benaud has died aged 84 in a Sydney hospice. The iconic broadcaster passed away peacefully in his sleep overnight. He had been receiving radiation treatment for skin cancer since November. As a player, Benaud was the first player from any nation to score 2000 Test runs and take 200 Test wickets. He was instrumental in the formation of World Series Cricket in the 1970s.

Hill was diagnosed with Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma, a rare childhood brain cancer shortly after her 18th birthday. She was told she had less than two years left to live and doctors told her they would move the school's opening game forward because of her worsening condition. But as her condition worsened, Hill became an honorary coach and raised more than $1.5 million for cancer research. On November 2, she scored the first and last baskets in Mount St. Joseph University's 66-55 victory.

He has a floating charge on the club and is prohibited from going over 10 per cent. Two of his closest associates - Derek Llambias and Barry Leach - sat as directors. Rangers have been fined £5,500 by the Scottish Football Association.

The incredible moment over 1000 spider crabs formed a pyramid during their pre-migration has been caught on camera by an underwater photographer. The video shows the creatures crawling in an upwards direction, presumably to get higher up. Spider crabs migrate once a year in the Port Phillip Bay area in Southern Victoria, piling on top of each other to create a moving mound.

US YouTube user Elman511 cracked open an over-sized egg that was laid by one of his hens, exclaiming: 'The big egg has another normal egg in it!' In a counter-peristalsis contraction, a second oocyte is released by the hen's ovary before the first egg has completed its journey. This results in an egg with another made inside it, producing two yolks.

Sportsmail's Racing Correspondent Marcus Townend and Britain's No 1 tipster Sam Turner cast their eye over the 39-strong field for the Grand National at Aintree. Will AP McCoy's glittering career conclude with a fairytale victory for favourite Shutthefrontdoor, a result that would cause 70,000 spectators to raise the roof? Or will one of the other contenders take place in history?

A Florida homeowner was shocked to find a nine foot long bull shark swimming right past his back door. The extremely dangerous predator is seen just under the water, with its distinctive pectoral fin breaking the surface. Homeowners say fishermen are chumming the water - which has been luring the animals back to their homes. Bull sharks are considered among the deadliest in the world, and among the most likely to attack humans.

McGregor is preparing for his world title fight against UFC featherweight champion Jose Aldo at the MGM Grand venue on May 2. James Toney lost in the first round when he fought Randy Couture in the UFC in 2010.

ARU passed a new policy which will allow experienced Wallabies playing at foreign clubs to be selected for test matches. Players with over 60 caps who have held professional contract with Australian Rugby for at least seven years will be eligible to continue their careers even if they are signed to a club overseas. The ARU's parlous financial position has made it hard for them to counter offers from wealthy European clubs.

John Brown was part of Celtic's semi-final defeat to Inverness in 1989. He was involved in a touchline tussle with Roy Aitken that saw him take a throw-in that should have gone the other way. The referee then gave Rangers a penalty, but no penalty was given.

Celtic were 2-1 down in an Old Firm League Cup final at Hampden Park. But Hartson has called on his former club to move on from the injustice.

The Ibrox legend worked closely with McCoist and coach Kenny McDowall before the duo assumed the reins at Rangers during four years of unprecedented turmoil off and on the pitch. Police have released images of football fans seen tending to the wounded at the 1989 Hillsborough disaster. Photographs show men and women rushing towards those crushed in one section of the ground. Coroner Sir John Goldring said the appeal was necessary as those photographed may be able to answer questions of victims' families. Ninety-six people were killed when Liverpool fans in one section of the football grounds became crushed. The conclusions of previous inquests were thrown out at the High Court in 2012 after years of campaigning by the families of those killed.

Earthflow is a viscous flow of fine-grained materials saturated with water that moves downhill because of the pull of gravity. It's slower than a mud flow, which can cover villages beneath mud in minutes. Climbers have long suspected hotter summers trigger rockfalls on Mont Blanc. New study shows 95 per cent of rockfalls around the mountain occur during between June and September - the hottest months of the year.

The latest version of the long-running game series, due out in the shops on July 16, features a number of new features, including various gameplay styles and enhanced ball physics.

A group of about half a dozen men began harassing them on a near-empty bus. They made several attempts to'molest' Arshdeep and her mother, but instead of defending them, the bus staff joined in the sexual assault. Mrs Kaur ran through the bus to tell the conductor to stop the bus, but he started driving faster. Shortly after they were thrown off the bus and the 14-year-old died in hospital.

Ba Van Nguyen was able to fly a Chinook helicopter with his family out of Saigon on April 30, 1975. He managed to get out of his flight suit and jump into the water seconds before the ship crashed. The Chinook was too small to withstand large amounts of shrapnel, which would likely cause the death of everyone on board. After being reunited with his family in 2009, he was awarded an air medal for bravery.

The new fuel was developed by Audi along with Sunfire, a Dresden-based energy technology company. To make the fuel, water is first heated to form steam, which is then broken down into its constituent hydrogen and oxygen using electrolysis. Hydrocarbons are the basic building block of all fossil fuels but the compounds produced in the reactor are known as 'blue crude'
The revolutionary system is being commercialised by French company Pixium Vision. It uses a technique known as 'neuromodulation' in which electricity from a chip stimulates the nervous system to restore sight. A connected 'pocket processor' converts that recording into an infrared image, which the goggles then beam into the eye. Following surgery, patients have to train their brains to interpret the new images.

Researchers subjected two commercial Li-ion batteries to external heat. They then used thermal imaging and non-invasive high speed imaging techniques to observe changes in their internal structure. Copper material inside Cell 1 melted, indicating internal temperatures of at least 1,085°C. It caused jets of molten material to stream from the battery’s vent. The rapid pressure rise in Cell 2 caused the entire cap of the battery to detach.
Rare and valuable meteorite may have landed in the Irish Sea, experts say. Footage shows it glowing brightly as it races northwards towards Earth. It was captured on camera by the United Kingdom Meteor Observing Network. It comes after astronomers revealed that they believe a meteor triggered the conversion of biblical figure Paul, one of the most influential figures in early Christianity.
Photographer Jessica Fulford-Dobson took pictures of young girls skateboarding in Kabul, Afghanistan. Skateistan is a non-profit organization that connects youth in Afghanistan with education through skateboarding. 40 per cent of the program's students are female; the girls also have the option of joining a free back-to-school program.
Nasa has been testing a flexible wing on a plane in California. Wing can bend from -2 degrees up to 30 degrees. It means regular flaps aren't needed and it is much lighter. The breakthrough could increase fuel efficiency up to 12 per cent. It could also reduce noise at take-off and landing up to 40 per cent.

the third largest of its kind in the world – rises sharply so ships can pass underneath. The Eshima Ohashi bridge in Japan is the largest rigid frame bridge in the world and the third largest in the world. Suspended across the Sidhue River in China, it is the world's highest vehicular bridge and still taller than the Eiffel Tower at its highest point.

Researchers at Stanford University School of Medicine used laboratory-engineered antibodies to target a wide range of solid tumours. They found primary tumours and distant metastases could be eradicated using the same approach as other potential treatments. The process relies on the same mechanism as which causes animals' bodies to reject organ transplants, they said.

They are among the first of 2,800 living veterans who will receive the honour in the months to come.

Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran were caught trying to smuggle more than eight kilograms of heroin out of Indonesia in 2005. The pair, from stable families, believed they were stuck in dead end jobs and looked on with jealousy at the flashy lifestyle that selling drugs promised. They both appealed their sentences and were eventually sentenced to death by firing squad. Now 13 years later, all seven men have been sentenced to life in prison, while Renae Lawrence is the only Bali Nine member who was given a reduced sentence of 20 years.
Scientists at Haverford College in Pennsylvania, US, found X-ray emissions consistent with thousands of white dwarf stars. These are stars left behind when larger stars - including our sun - run out of fuel. Why thousands of these stars are here remains a mystery.

Bruno Smartcan is said to be the first internet connected combined kitchen bin and vacuum cleaner. It uses sensors on the front of the bin to sense when dust is swept towards it with a brush, turning on a vacuum to suck up the offending mess. It also has an integrated bag dispenser that additionally sends alerts to a smartphone when it is time to take out the trash.

The House Judiciary Committee passed the latest version of a bill known as the USA Freedom Act on Thursday by a bipartisan vote of 25 to 2. It would allow the agency to request certain records held by the telephone companies under a court order in terrorism investigations. The authority to collect those records and other related surveillance provisions of the Patriot Act will expire June 1 unless Congress passes a law reauthorizing it. Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is seemingly out of phase, sponsoring his own bill to extend the bill until the end of 2020.

The fossils were unearthed at a sea cliff along the Caribbean coast of Panama. They show that at one time small sperm whales measuring around seven feet had a much larger spermaceti organ relative to their size than modern day relatives. This organ plays a key role in the generation of sound and in the whale’s capacity for echolocation. The find will help experts fill in gaps in the evolution of cetaceans.
Scientists have uncovered the mystery of Mercury's'stealth' colour scheme. They say a steady dusting of carbon from passing comets has slowly painted Mercury black over billions of years. The spacecraft is expected to smash into the planet's surface on Thursday 30 April at 3:30pm Eastern Time.

Scientists from the University of Connecticut warned that one in every six species of animals are at risk of extinction. If future temperatures increase by only two degrees compared to pre-industrial levels, the extinction risk would rise to 5.2%. But if global warming maintains its trajectory and a 4.3 degree increase, that could increase to 16%, they say.

Scientists in Switzerland tricked brains of test subjects into feeling an unexpected 'presence' They used a robot to interfere with the sensory signals in the brains of blindfolded volunteers. Researchers from the University of Patras took thermal infrared photographs of 41 volunteers’ faces, before and after drinking four glasses of wine. They found that the temperature of the forehead, and to a lesser extent, the nose, is the best indication of a person’s drunken state. The algorithm could one day be installed in cars to spot drink drivers and stop them starting the ignition. Drunken speech hallmarks include stammering and stuttering.

Blue Origin company has completed a successful spaceflight test in West Texas. The New Shepard vehicle rose to a height of 58 miles - four miles short of the official boundary of space. It will eventually take six people into space, providing opportunities for researchers to fly experiments into microgravity. Test flight came as somewhat of a surprise because the company didn't make any announcements in the build up that it would be launching a rocket.

Researchers studied stone tools that were used by people in the Early Ahmarian culture and the Protoaurignacian culture around 40,000 years ago. They found the human tools were no more effective than Neanderthal-created tools of the same era. This contradicts one theory that early modern humans 'bullied' their Neanderthal cousins to the point of extinction because they had better tools to survive.

Researchers at Yahoo Labs in California have created a sensor that can recognise the shape of your ear, your palm or any other body part you want to use to access your device. Called Bodyprint, the technology turns a standard touchscreen into a biometric scanner removing the need to specialist hardware such as fingerprint readers or infrared cameras. To accept an incoming call, users would only need to press their ear against the phone.

Scientists at the University of Arizona studied the anatomy of a beetle's reaction chamber. They found that the chemical mixture in the abdomen is extremely elastic, causing it to expand and impinge on the valve that separates the two chambers. When threatened, the beetle can repeatedly fire streams of foul-smelling liquid from its rear, complete with 'gun smoke'

The City of Akron purchased the title to the stadium from the City of Akron for $1 in 1971. The Zips left the stadium in 2009 and moved into InfoCision Stadium. The best way to revive a stale loaf of bread is to run it under water. It doesn't matter if the water is hot or cold, just keep the cut edge away from the direct flow of water. When you have wet your bread put it in the oven for between 6 and 13 minutes. Nutritionist Luvisa Nillson says that this trick does actually work, but you must make sure to eat the bread that same day.

Researchers from Cornell University, eBay Research Labs and the University of California, Berkeley, have addressed the problem in a new paper. They found that items with precise prices attract higher offers than those with more specific prices. Sellers who end their price with '00' typically receive offers that are five to eight per cent lower than if they are with more specific prices.

Astronomers watched a star take shape over eight years using a telescope in the New Mexico desert in the U.S. The first image was taken with the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array in 1996, and the second by an international team led by the National Autonomous University of Mexico last year. They show how the electrified wind that is being ejected from the star has expanded dramatically as it takes shape.
Researchers at the University of Illinois College of Medicine studied brain development in rats exposed to alcohol for two days on, then two days off. They found that the rats' DNA was less tightly coiled than if they had been exposed to alcohol weeks before. This put them at risk of anxiety disorders and alcoholism, they said. A cancer drug known to block the activity of HDAC2 could be used to reverse the damage.

Phoj is a bike seat and stroller in one. It clips onto the back of a standard bike using a specially-designed attachment. A child, up to a height of 3.2ft, is then strapped into the seat in an almost vertical position. The parent cycles to their destination, and once they arrive, can unclip the seat and push it like a regular buggy.

'Marilyn Einstein' was created by superimposing a blurry picture of Monroe over a picture of Albert Einstein drawn in fine lines. Hybrid images show how the brain processes information, and can be hidden with textures, words and other objects. Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology say these images not only reveal vision problems, but can also highlight how the brain processes information.
'Flute' found in Slovenia may have been made by Neanderthals 130,000 years ago. It is believed to have been chewed by hyenas to serenade their companions. But new research suggests many bones are simply chew toys of animals.

Researchers from Heriot-Watt University and University College London are developing a computer that can collate meterological information and then produce forecasts as if they were written by a human. The project is called Domain-Independent Language Generation and is being run by Dr Verena Rieser from Heriot-Watt University's School of Mathematical and Computer Science. If the project is successful, a prototype system will be tested by generating local weather updates on the BBC's website.

Genes For Good is a Facebook app designed to survey the health of millions of users. Users can send in spit samples to tie their survey results to their genes. After withdrawing, they are presented with health surveys they can complete each day. Results include genetic ancestry as well as raw genetic data in a securely encrypted computer file.

A lunar eclipse occurs when the moon passes through the edge of the earth's shadow. This is an area known as the umbra, where light from the Sun is blocked by our planet. A total lunar eclipse occurs when the moon is completely in the earth's shadow. Wet and cloudy weather was to blame in Sydney, but the Observatory captured every moment with its equipment. In Darwin, a 20 per cent chance of rain was forecast for Hobart, but it could still be cloudy.

Dr Milton Wainwright has been trying to convince academics that he has found aliens in Earth's stratosphere for several years. He says the organisms test positive for DNA, and have masses that are six times bigger than the size limit of a particle which can be elevated from Earth to this height. His findings have been accepted in the journal Astrobiology and Outreach.

Scientists found a new type of virus that infects the primitive forms of life that live beneath the surface of the Earth. The tiny bacteria known as nanoarchaea targetted four distinct genes. They actively caused one of their own genes to mutate - allowing them to develop new ways of coping with the environment they find themselves in. Researchers believe it may be viruses like this that actually hold the secret that have allowed archae bacteria to adapt to some of the harshest environments on Earth.

Researchers from the University of Connecticut studied a Neanderthal child's ear bone. They found that, as a sound gets further away, our brains are able to work out its differences in its maximum and minimum volume - and thus its distance. Without amplitude modulation, a person can't tell how far away a noise is from them.

It was previously thought that the hairy beast simply died out from post-Ice Age climate change and being hunted to extinction by early man. But now a new theory is set to re-write the history books after examination of more than 23,500 mammoth bones found riddled with osteoporosis. The major mineral deficiency - which came from the impact of rising temperatures on soil and water - resulted in mammoths breaking their limbs and spines, leaving them unable to forage for food, or flee hunters.

Engineers plan to tap into a Roman drain where 850,000 litres of natural spring water empties every day into the ground. They hope to divert the warm water instead through a network of underground pipes to provide a world-first natural underfloor heating system for Bath Abbey. The idea is, that if this energy was harnessed correctly and converted, it could produce 1.5 megawatts of continuous energy.

Researchers in Namibia have found a similar pattern in two apparently unrelated places - cells in human skin and the mysterious fairy circles. Scientists claim older buildings where hauntings are usually reported, often have poor air quality from pollutants like toxic mould. Ebola vaccine is based on an animal virus called vesicular stomatitis virus. It is combined with a portion of the protein covering of the Ebola virus. When administered, it induces an immune response against the virus. Scientists hope that immunisation is possible with just one injection.

The superbug sickened at least 243 people, in 32 states and Puerto Rico.

Scientists studied the movement of ocean waves at the bottom of the seabed. These waves are known as long because they travel from the floor to the coast and back again. This helps create long seismic waves, that oscillate much slower. The hum is the least understood part of Earth's oscillations, said the researchers.
There will be more Muslims than Christians in the world in less than 60 years, Pew Research Center has claimed. By 2100 around one per cent more of the world’s population will be Muslim than Christian, with the largest proportion of the religion's followers in India. Several countries are also projected to have a different religious majority by 2050.

Biologist Dr Joe Hanson has worked out what the human body would look like as a chemical formula. He says a human molecule might contain 375 million atoms of hydrogen, 132 million atoms of oxygen and 85 million atoms of carbon. His formula is only representative of the chemical make up of the human body at birth. The average adult human body contains 16kg of carbon and enough oxygen to fill a volume equivalent to 6 elephants.

The strange formation was photographed by amateur astronomer Gordon Ewen, from Letchworth, Hertfordshire. The large telescope focuses on a specific wavelength of light and allows him to see the details created on the sun's surface. Sun spots range in size, from just 10 miles to 100,000 miles wide - big enough to be seen from Earth without a telescope.

The Sokaze-ki Q uses fluid dynamics to take air in small inlets on the rear before it is moved using so-called impellers. This airflow pulls in additional air from air inlets plotted around the Q, and all of this is released through the main outlet. The fan is on sale in Japan for 39,350 and is available in Crystal Red, Champagne Gold and Pearl White.

The lunar eclipse this month will appear in Sydney's north-eastern sky. A lunar eclipse occurs when the moon passes in the shadow of Earth. This is an area known as the umbra, where light from the Sun is blocked by our planet. A partial or penumbral eclipse is also known as a total lunar eclipse. It is the third in a series of four blood moons, with the final one expected on September 28.

Scientists in Italy have extracted the oldest ever DNA sample to be taken from a Neanderthal. The team say samples of DNA have also been retrieved from the sample, and because of the age, represent the oldest such samples ever recovered from Neanderthal remains. Researchers believe it could reveal new details about the evolution of hominids in general and the early history of the ancient Neanderthals.

Photographer Victor Albert Prout travelled along the River Thames in a makeshift boat, taking pictures of well known landmarks. His collection is believed to be the oldest documented record of Britain's greatest river, dating back more than 150 years. Some of the images are instantly recognisable today, with some showing how little things have changed. The collection will be sold as a collection at the Oxford Book Fair and is estimated to sell for around £30,000.

The timing of pollination in Ephedra foeminea varied considerably from year to year, but was correlated with the full moon of July. It may not turn into a bloodthirsty beast in the moonlight, but a peculiar plant does rely on the lunar cycle to survive. At night, the non-flowering relative of conifers secretes tiny droplets of sugary fluid to attract pollinating insects.

Scientists hope to see dark matter for the first time ever thanks to upgrade. The Large Hadron Collider is situated underground near the border between Switzerland and France. It was shut down two years ago after confirming the existence of the Higgs boson. But it has now been upgraded to a record-breaking 13 tera-electron volts in June.

Engineers believe super absorbent properties of tampons could be used to detect pipes that shunt sewage into streams instead of treatment plants. Tampons absorb chemicals commonly used on toilet paper, laundry detergents and shampoos, which glow under UV light. They found that nine of the tampons glowed, confirming the presence of optical brighteners - and therefore sewage pollution.

Scientists studied fossilised cone snail shells that are up to 6.6 million years old. They were covered in streaks of orange, purple, blue and even pokadots. This is because the pigments in the shells oxidise over time. It is thought this causes them to light up when UV light is shined on them. The researchers believe the cone snails, which come from the northern Dominican Republic, include 13 entirely new species.

The washing machine-sized Philae lander is currently in orbit around comet 67P. It was launched into space in 2004 using the gravity of Earth and Mars. But it failed to fire harpoons that would have kept it attached to the comet. This resulted in it bouncing to a height of 0.62 miles above the comet's surface. On 14 April, scientists hope to hear from the lander on the surface.

California Gov. Jerry Brown ordered a 25 percent overall cutback in urban water use by cities and towns in the golden state on Wednesday. The crackdown comes as California and its nearly 40 million residents move toward a fourth summer of drought with no relief in sight. State reservoirs have a year's worth of water, and with record low snowfall over the winter there won't be much to replenish them.

Curiosity rover has discovered strange, multi-coloured mineral veins on Mars that could give astronomers new clues to its watery past. Scientists believe the bizarre formed in Mars' wet past billions of years ago above the now eroded, much softer bedrock. The veins contain both bright and dark material.

Researchers analysed 1,204 retired people with investments between 2006 and 2008. They found that more than 50 per cent of pensioners with investments during the 2007 and 2008 global financial crisis panicked and sold them after the stock market fell by 30 per cent. If they had resisted the temptation to sell, the same pot would only have £63,000 today provided they had not spent any of the cash.

Researchers believe the very first rudimentary communication between humans took place around 50,000 to 100,000 years ago. They found cavemen grunted and pointed before learning to speak in a detailed way. But single words bear traces of syntax showing that they must be descended from an older, syntax-laden system, rather than from simple, primal utterances.

Dr Raychelle Burks from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln explains why stress is bad for you in a video. She says that prolonged periods of stress can inhibit the immune system and even make your bones more fragile. Cortisol is released when the body is in 'fight or flight' mode, meaning it's less likely to fight back.
Pet aquarium fish are being dumped in WA's waterways where they damage unique local ecosystems by growing up to twenty times their regular size. At least 13 species of fish have been introduced into south-western Australia, with pet owners believed to be the biggest culprits. Many countries with Mediterranean climates have also had their waterways invaded by aquarium fish which, due to being extremely easy to breed, take off when in the wild.

Graphic designer Martin Vargic used satellite data to chart how the constellations have shifted over time. He estimates how many of the most distinctive of the constellations will become almost unrecognisable in the future. The results suggest that some of the most abstract constellations may need to be renamed entirely.

ESA's Asteroid Impact Mission, or AIM, is a part of the larger Asteroid Impact & Deflection Assessment mission. The mission will take place in two parts, and this month marked the start of preliminary design work on AIM. AIM's findings will be returned by high-capacity laser link to ESA's Optical Ground Station on Tenerife in the Canary Islands.

The liquid is called Shear-Thickening Fluid, and instantly hardens upon impact at any temperature. It does not conform to Newtonian liquids, such as water, in which the force required to move the fluid faster exponentially increases. In a 'liquid armour' this provides protection from penetration by high-speed projectiles and additionally dispersing energy over a larger area.

Dr Celia Sanchez-Ramos is an optometrist at Complutense University in Madrid. She found that LED screens can harm the retina - the light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye. In extreme cases, she says, it may even lead to macular degeration, which causes dark patches to appear in the centre of the field of vision. Modern LED screens emit up to five times as much blue light as older technology.

Currency was collected from students at the University of Surrey. It was then submerged in agar - a substance that allows bacteria to grow quickly. Most common type of bacteria they found on the coins was bacillus mycoides, which is common in soil, suggesting someone was gardening before handling cash. Researchers from Duke University in North Carolina studied rats in a specially made cage. They found that rats flatten their ears, narrow their eyes and puff up their cheeks when they are in pain. This suggests that as well as expressing their emotional state, the pained faces of rodents may have a ‘communicative function’

Singer-songwriter Don McLean's original manuscript and notes to 'American Pie' have been sold at auction for $1.2 million. The 16 pages include the original working manuscript and typed drafts of the song, including tantalizing new details about the famous anthem. It has long been known that the song about 'the day the music died' refers to February 3, 1959, when rock n' roll icon Buddy Holly and fellow singers Ritchie Valens and J.P. 'Big Bopper' Richardson also died in a plane crash alongside Buddy Holly.
Bans on texting and driving may be preventing deadly car accidents in the United States, says a new study. Hospitalizations from car crashes dropped 7 percent between 2003 and 20010 in the 45 states with texting bans. The study's leader Alva Ferdinand said that the greatest benefit was seen in states where texting bans are strictly enforced.

He may be suffering from retrograde amnesia, an inability to remember any events that occurred shortly before the accident or illness. Amnesia is usually caused by disease or head injury, but in rare cases, it can last months or even years.

Professor Bryan Sykes believes her ancestors came out of Africa over 100,000 years ago.

The Cheyenne Mountain Complex is a self-contained and sufficient town buried under the Rockies to be impervious to a Soviet nuclear attack. It was built in the 1960s for the North American Aerospace Defense Command, which monitored the skies for threats like missiles, aircraft and space objects. But in 2006, the Pentagon decided to move the headquarters of NORAD and US Northern Command from Cheyenne to Petersen Air Force Base in Colorado Springs. The move follows hundreds of millions of dollars worth of modernization work done at the base.
Seven of the world's most endangered crocodiles flew out of Melbourne on Wednesday en route to their native country. The 40 centimetre-long Philippine crocs travelled in custom-designed boxes specially built by Melbourne Zoo to ensure they had a smooth flight. The arrival of these one year olds to the Palawan Wildlife Rescue & Conservation Centre in southern Philippines is part of a major conservation effort for the endangered species.

Genetic analysis of ancient human remains shows that European populations were still evolving until relatively recently. Researchers from Harvard University in Massachusetts found five genes associated with changes in diet, body size and skin pigmentation. These genes are known to account for 25-40 per cent of the skin tone lightening in Europeans. The study suggests Caucasians were a recent addition to the area, arriving on the continent 8,000 years ago.

Researchers at the University of Montana found that eating fast food after a workout may be just as beneficial as dietary supplements. Performance remained the same after resting for several hours, while levels of glycogen - used by muscles as ‘fuel’ - were actually slightly higher after fast food was eaten as a recovery food.

It details a method of scanning a user's face with the front-facing camera each time the phone is moved into a certain position. If the scanned face matches a previously taken photo, the phone unlocks automatically.

Researchers at Virginia Tech College of Agriculture and Life Sciences recruited 150 children aged between seven and 10 and gave them a task-switching game to complete. They found that after five days of eating lots of fat, the muscles' ability to oxidise glucose was disrupted, meaning that it wasn't broken down into energy as easily. Children who ate diets higher in saturated fats and cholesterol had slower reaction times and a poorer working memory.

Researchers from Oxford University studied brains of tiny babies. They found that young babies are more sensitive to pain than adults. It overturns the medical consensus that newborns have a high pain threshold. Up until now doctors had assumed the brains of very young babies were not developed enough to feel pain. But new findings suggest that not only do babies feel pain, but their pain thresholds are even lower than those of adults.

Scientists at UCLA examined the brains of 90 women taking the Pill. They found the lateral orbitofrontal cortex and the posterior cigulate cortex were thinner in those taking the pill. Pleasaunce Cottage in East Grinstead is one of the last surviving bungalows in Britain that were built on the design of Victorian houses in India. It has four bedrooms, four reception rooms and two bathrooms, one of which is en-suite. Built in the late 19th Century by architect RA Briggs, the term was used to describe small, country homes used by the wealthy upper classes.

Researchers from Stanford and Cornell University studied 40 million posts on news site CNN. They found that FBUs contribute significantly more posts per thread they participate in, and were more likely to have had more posts deleted than NBUs. These individual traits are unlikely to help recognise a troll or antisocial behaviour in their own right but when combined the researchers found they could identify a troll with an accuracy of 80 per cent.

The Megalithic site of Gunung Padang was discovered in 1914. It is the largest site of its kind in Indonesia. Geologist Dr Danny Hilman believes the site is culturally important because it is an ancient pyramid which was built between 9,000 and 20,000 years ago. He suggests that it may have been built for worship or astronomy.

Emma Dickson, 31, developed a condition called pulmonary embolisms. She was taken to hospital with a collapsed lung just a month before her wedding. Doctors told her she had developed the condition as a result of taking the pill. The pill contains synthetic hormones which can cause blood clots. They could have moved to her brain, causing a stroke and lead to severe headaches. Mrs Dickson has now been given blood-thinning medication to keep her alive.

Rhondda Tunnel was closed as part of the Beeching cutbacks 50 years ago. It would be one of the longest cycle tunnels in the world, second only to the 4,000m Snoqualmie Tunnel near Seattle in the U.S. Engineer Sydney William Yockney oversaw the five-year building project. The tunnel lay dormant for nearly 50 years after being abandoned. But engineers are due to visit the 3,148m tunnel next week to see if it is safe.

Feral rabbits, which are deemed a pest in NSW, are liekly to be targeted with the Calicivirus. It comes after over 30 government bodies scattered carrots laced with calicivirus around public areas in March. The virus damages the animal's liver and gut and causes haemorrhaging and bleeding. Rabbits compete with native wildlife for food and habitat and are believed to be responsible for the extinction of and population decline of a number of mammals.

This could see the prices of these fish soar, or see them being taken off the menu completely.

Durham University scientists studied a clump of dark matter that appears to be lagging behind a galaxy by 5,000 light-years. This is important because it is only possible if dark matter interacts with itself through forces other than gravity. It follows on from research by the same team last month that found dark matter interacts with itself very little.

Deep brain stimulation is already used to treat Parkinson's disease. Researchers now believe it could be used to boost memory and ward off diseases such as dementia. A 'brain pacemaker' fitted with electrodes is inserted directly into the skull through holes drilled in the skull. It sends electrical impulses to specific parts of the brain, and has also been shown to provide benefits for a range of conditions including chronic pain, major depression and obsessive compulsive disorder.

The Michigan Micro Mote is the smallest computer in the world, measuring less than two millimeters across. It contains solar cells that power the battery with ambient light, including indoor rooms with no natural sunlight, allowing the computers to run perpetually. One key application for this line of smart sensors lies in personal security and information, its inventors say.

Researchers in Peru's Cotahuasi Valley have recovered 171 broken mummies from the ancient ceremonial site known as Tenahaha. They are thought to have been used over many years, and likely changed during that time. One theory is that the movement of the mummies may have helped create a sense of equality among the community. In one tomb, researchers discovered 400 isolated human body parts, including teeth, hands and feet.

Nasa has released incredible point-of-view footage taken by astronauts on spacewalks of the International Space Station. Astronauts Barry Wilmore and Terry Virts recorded three spacewalks, known as Extra Vehicular Activities, on GoPro cameras outside the ISS on February 25 and March 1. The spacewalks were in preparation for the arrival of multibillion pound commercial spacecraft, which Nasa hope will be in operation by 2017.

The varied surface of the moon has been revealed in stunning detail by the US Geological Survey. The two sets of maps, compiled by cartographer Trent Hare, include image mosaics and topographical views of the lunar landscape taken over a period of four years. Early theories claimed the mysterious region, roughly 1,600 miles across, was created by an asteroid impact. But scientists have now suggested that the feature is actually the result of the formation of ancient rift valleys.

Miconazole and clobetasol both restored movement to mice paralysed by multiple sclerosis, scientists claim. The anti-fungal agent miconazole and the steroid clobetasol coaxed the inactive OPCs to regenerate myelin, the protective coating around nerve fibres that is damaged. The discovery could pave the way to ground-breaking new therapies for MS, which affects around 2.5 million worldwide.

Potatoes. YouTuber Dave Hax’s ingenious new kitcken trick lets cooks peel potatoes without using a peeler. The method starts by running the blade of a sharp knife carefully around the middle of the potato, without letting it cut through. Then turn the spud around and do the same on the other side... and voila!

‘Visualize You’ processes an image of you to reveal what you would look like if you lost a specified amount weight. App has been developed with the Wellness Institute of the Cleveland Clinic, the University of Colorado Anschutz Health and Wellness Centre, and UnitedHealthcare.

Scientists say they have detected gases as far a field as Antarctica. They say they are having an increasing effect on the Earth's climate. Anaesthetic is used to send patients to sleep during surgery. The gases escape from hospital operating rooms via air vents. One kilogram of desflurane produces the same effect as 2,500 kg of carbon dioxide.
Researchers from Lancaster University studied the brains of people reading seven Harry Potter novels. They selected 120 passages, each of which were four lines long and did not require a high level of familiarity with the books. They rated them on valence - from -3 for very negative to +3 for very positive - and arousal - on a scale of 1 for very calming to 5 for very arousing. The emotional impact is said to result from the drift of Harry's mind into the past remembering his relationship with Ginny.

Researchers at George Washington University examined ancient pollen and charcoal samples from the Sea of Galilee. They found evidence of a 150 year drought between 1250BC and 1100BC. The drought brought fires, famine and social unrest to the region. However Professor Eric Cline says that as each of these great societies were intertwined, the misery of one was shared by others. He suggests ISIS could be the modern day equivalent of the Sea Peoples.

He has been sentenced to death after being found guilty of murder.

A Utah photographer, Alan Lawrence, created a photo series in which his 18-month-old son, Wil, who has Down Syndrome appears to be flying. The father of five, who began taking the photos when Wil was just months old, created the illusion by holding his son up in the photos and later cropping himself out. After receiving positive feedback, Lawrence decided to compile the photos in a calendar and plans to donate half the proceeds to two Down Syndrome foundations.

According to court documents, the 23-year-old left the US a year ago with the intent to go to Syria and train with a terrorist group affiliated with al Qaeda in Iraq. The Justice Department stated that Mohamud was also an Islamic State sympathizer, and that his brother, Abdifatah Aden, was killed fighting with the group in Syria in 2013.
Blue Origin is among a handful of companies planning to offer commercial spaceflight services. The so-called New Shepard system will take astronauts to space on suborbital journeys. It will launch from Blue Origin's west Texas facility near Van Horn, Texas, southeast of El Paso. Blue Origin has not started selling tickets for flights on New Shepard or released pricing information.

Between iPhones, flat-screens and designer headphones, Australians are spending more on technology than ever. A new report from Suncorp Bank suggests Australian's have spent 50 per cent more on digital devices than they planned in the last year. Mobile phone bills were the biggest expense, and also the biggest disparity for families. Men spent twice as much as women on computers, digital accessories, mobile apps, and streaming services.

Scientists quizzed more than 5,000 British 15-year-olds about their drinking habits and the films they had watched from a list of 50. Those who had watched the most alcohol scenes were 20 per cent more likely to have tried alcohol and 70 per cent more likely to binge drink. Children who had watched the most alcohol scenes were two-and-a-half times more likely to have a drink more than once per week.

He was then able to pull the man out to safety. Sitko posted on Facebook that he was 'blessed' and is now recovering. Warnock has been named as the hero.

The futuristic new system – dubbed SpiderFab – is being developed by a company called Tethers Unlimited. The system uses arachnid-like robots to construct large objects in orbit around the Earth by'spinning' building material into shape.

Number of Christians in the US will decline from three quarters of the population in 2010 to just two thirds in 2050. By 2050, there will be 2.8billion Muslims and 2.9billion Christians, according to Pew Research Center projections. The percentage of those who do not affiliate with any religion is expected to fall across the same time frame. A number of countries are expected to have changing religious majorities in four decades.

Stiviano's lawyer said there was no clear documentation that funds went from Sterling's real estate company to Stiviano's bank accounts. The judge also ordered Stiviano to pay his wife $1 million in cash.
Researchers at the U.S. National Cancer Institute are using the vaccine on 70 men who have been treated for the cancer. The study found that injecting the vaccine into warts that had resisted other treatments led to six out of ten disappearing. Side-effects included pain during injection, itching and flu-like symptoms.

The 59-year-old has spent 40 years as an officer in three different states, but nothing compares to the immense heat and desolate conditions. McShane said the wildest incident in his stint, the 2010 Birdsville Races, was the wildest incident in the town, which saw 5000 people inside the small town.

Lake Teller in Boulder, Colorado, has been invaded by 3,000 to 4,000 goldfish. Wildlife officials say the fish started as someone dumping 'four or five' of their pets in the water two or three years ago. The animals are now threatening to over-run the natural species in the lake, by eating up all their resources and spreading unnatural diseases.

Plague is most commonly carried by fleas and rodents, and is contracted by as many as 2,000 people a year. Modern medications are effective in fighting the disease, though it can be deadly if left untreated.

Neanderthals may have been the world's first gourmets, according to new research. Researchers found traces of compounds in camomile and yarrow in the hardened plaque of 50,000 year old teeth found in El Sidron, Spain. They say they could have used herbs to make food more palatable. This suggests they were skilled tool makers with adept hand eye coordination.

Lorraine Valentine has erythropoietic protoporphyria which causes skin to burn. It is caused by a shortage of an enzyme in the body that converts protoporphyrin into a substance called haem. As blood passes through the skin, this absorbs energy and sets off a chemical reaction that can cause skin to swell. When she is in pain, even going to the supermarket is painful. Miss Valentine is now fundraising for the British Porphyria Association.
The key is to maintain an even balance of 'energy in' and 'energy out' It takes 30 to 40 minutes of physical exercise to burn off even the smallest of Easter treats. A small chocolate Easter egg would take 30 to 40 minutes of swimming to work off. An 80 kilogram male would need to paddle for half an hour longer than a female of average weight to burn it off.

'Nail' houses in China are known as 'dingzihu' or 'nail houses' because they stick out and are difficult to remove, like a stubborn nail. One house in Wenling, Zhejiang province, had a main road built around it when the owner refused to move. Another image shows a single-storey ramshackle house sitting alone in a crater at the centre of a construction site in Chongqing Municipality.

The pair met when he was a sixth-grade student in her second grade class and went on to have a sexual relationship with him when he was 12. Before she was arrested, she fell pregnant with his first daughter and gave birth to their second after she was released from jail. They married a year later at a Washington winery.
Researchers unearthed the bones of two adults and a child in France. They suggest that Neanderthals may have eaten deceased friends and family either for food or in bizarre funeral rituals. Similar marks have been seen at other Neanderthal sites showing how our ancestors cut and fractured the bones of their dead relatives.

Linden Gledhill from Staffordshire took the photos using a trinocular-reflecting light microscope fitted with Neo S-plan objectives. The 51-year-old uses a modified camera and a StackShot stepping motor to drive the focusing control. Scientists at the University of Maryland studied the composition of two moon rocks collected by the Apollo 16 mission. They found that 20 to 40 per cent of impactors had similar compositions to the planets they impacted. This is consistent with leading theories of the formation of the solar system.

Experts believe the Molalla Log Cabin could have been built as early as 1795 - ten years before Lewis and Clark reached the Pacific Ocean. The way the logs are tightly interwoven, secured without nails and leaving no gaps to fill, is similar to Russian log cabins of the same time period. They hope to find a permanent home for the 18-foot-wide structure.

The seven-car Maglev - short for'magnetic levitation' - hit a top speed of 375mph and travelled for almost 11 seconds at speeds above 373mph. The run beat last week's previous 12-year record of 361mph. Maglev trains use magnets to lift the carriages above the track, eliminating the need for wheels and therefore reduce friction. By 2045, Maglev trains are expected to link Tokyo and Osaka in just one hour and seven minutes, slashing the journey time in half.

Luca Railton was born with bones missing from his legs, due to the rare condition bilateral tibial hemimelia. At 10-years-old doctors said there was nothing more they could do for him, and he would need to have his right leg amputated or fused straight. But his family refused and began desperately searching for alternatives. They found an American surgeon called Dr Dror Paley who assured Luca's parents his leg could be saved and allow him to walk. He underwent a series of operations including one to break his right leg and start lengthening his right leg in three years time. Since his return, he has been able to walk without crutches, cricket and even hopes to drive cars.

Researchers from London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine analysed data on 1,958,191 patients aged 55 with a BMI of 26.5 on average. They found underweight people are a third more likely to be diagnosed with diseases such as Alzheimer's than those of a healthy weight. Obese people appear to be protected against dementia, with a risk around 30 per cent lower than those of a healthy weight.

Scientists have discovered a protein which helps boost the body’s immune system ten-fold, an astonishing effect which could help patients fight off cancers and viruses. They are now developing a gene therapy that would boost the production of LEM proteins, in turn increasing the number of T-cells available to attack cancer cells. Therapy would use existing T-cells taken from individual patients. The patient’s cells would be removed, modified with the insertion of LEM-producing genes, and then infused back into the patients via a drip, probably on four occasions over two months.

The Earth experienced its hottest month of March since record-keeping began in 1880. Last month's average temperature was 1.5°F above the 20th century average. This was the highest for March in the 1880–2015 record, surpassing the previous record of 2010 by 0.09°F. Scientists warn that fossil fuel burning is pushing more greenhouse gas into the atmosphere, leading to increased temperatures.

Sonnenspeicher uses a lithium iron phosphate battery to store energy harvested during the day by solar panels fitted to a roof. This energy is used throughout the day, and any excess is stored for when the sun goes down. Rather than selling this excess electricity back to the grid, homeowners can then use their stored supply for power.

Confederate General Robert E. Lee surrendered to Union forces in Appomattox, Virginia, on April 9, 1865. The battle was a milestone in the end of the American Civil War. Today is the 150th anniversary of Lee's surrender. Reenactors dressed as confederate cavalry spent the night in tents at Appomattox Court House National Historical Park.

Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen believes there was evidence of Costa's unstable mindset declining in the lead-up to the attack.

Eye2TV adapter allows colour blind people to watch TV without a loss of detail. It can be plugged into any HDMI port on a TV or a computer monitor. A remote control or app then adjusts the colour adjustment. The subtle effect is such that someone with normal vision will barely notice any change in the picture.

His parents said it was discouraging to tell a nine-year-old that he was too good at something. An amazing map revealed by Nasa has shown where lightning occurs most on Earth. The map reveals average yearly counts of lightning flashes per square kilometer from 1995 to 2013. And the results show that the highest amounts of lightning flashes occur in the far eastern Democratic Republic of Congo and Lake Maracaibo in northwestern Venezuela.

Scientists have long known that there is water in the form of ice on Mars. Now, new information from the Mars rover Curiosity shows that it is possible that there is liquid water close to the surface of the red planet. The explanation is that the substance calcium perchlorate has been found in the soil, which lowers the freezing point so the water does not freeze into ice.

Cannabis plants contain more than 60 unique compounds called cannabinoids. Two of the most common compounds are tetrahydrocannabinol and cannabidiol. CBD is not psychoactive, and has actually been found to reduce the effects of THC. Dogs and cats can take advantage of small amounts of CBD in biscuits. Canna-Pet sells boxes of CBD biscuits for $16.49 and these can be bought online in any state of the US, but not shipped internationally.

Rachel Simpson, 15, has a one-in-a-million genetic condition which doctors say will eventually give her cancer if untreated. Doctors ran blood tests - which revealed she had a mutation of the GATA2 gene. This is important in the production of blood cells, and the disorder means a sufferer's blood counts might be low, making them more vulnerable to infection. Or, the blood cells might be abnormal, leading to leukaemia.

The Atlantic Wall was a series of robust fortifications built after 1942 by the Nazis to defend against an anticipated Allied invasion. Mulberries, or artificial harbours as they were otherwise known, were designed to help the Allies unload the heavy cargoes associated with a large-scale invasion. The TrackYourDose app was developed by German firm esooka. It tracks cosmic radiation from flight altitudes and solar activity. A 10-hour flight across the North Atlantic, for instance, results in a radiation exposure of between 50 Sv to 100 Sv. By comparison, an X-ray at a dentist exposes patients to 6 Sv. A dose of 2,000,000 Sv is considered severe and potentially fatal.

Researchers at the University of Sheffield analysed people with a body mass index of 30 or more - a recognised measure of obesity. They found the largest cluster was 'younger healthy females' - also the youngest group. They were the group most likely to display positive health characteristics, and engaged in some healthy behaviours. The final group, made up of those with the 'poorest health' was the most deprived, had the highest prevalence of most chronic health conditions, and tended not to engage in healthy behaviours.

Researchers believe those who lived at the Rising Whale site may be part of what scientists call the 'Birnirk' culture. They are a group of people who lived on both sides of the Bering Strait and used skin boats and harpoons to hunt whales. The latest discovery was made after archaeologists found what they believe to be a bronze and leather buckle and a bronze whistle.

Researchers from New York University studied how our brain stores memories for 'neutral' or boring events, like a lunch date. Emotion affects activity in brain regions involved in emotional processing - such as the amygdala and striatum. This also affects regions involved in encoding new experiences, like the hippocampus. A nap of 45 minutes to an hour can boost memory by five times, researchers said.

French commander Georges Lamour saw a cloud of toxic gas drifting over Flanders Fields in April 1915. He cried: 'All my trenches are choked!' Some 1,200 French soldiers were killed in the chaos of that first five-minute gas attack. The last gas attack came just three days before the armistice of November 11, 1918. There is also evidence to suggest ISIS is using chlorine gas as a chemical weapon in its battle.

DNA extracted from bones found in cave in Altamura, Italy, matched that of Neanderthals. The ancient species may have used wild herbs to flavour their food. Scientists believe modern humans may also have interbred with Neanderthals.
The skeleton of Friedrich Branft, 22, was found under a car park at the Battle of Waterloo 200 years ago. It is the first complete skeleton to be recovered from the battle. Archaeologist Gareth Glover, 54, called the find ‘unique’ and explained that no complete skeleton had ever been retrieved from the battle.
Scientists analysed 57 species in the Fukushima region and found that the majority of populations had diminished as a result of the accident. One breed in particular had plummeted from several hundred before the 2011 disaster to just a few dozen today. This is despite radiation levels in the region starting to fall. Researchers hope to get information on what the future holds for Fukushima from the Chernobyl site.

Primatologists at Iowa State University recorded 300 hunts by chimps in Fongoli, Sénégal. They found females were using tools to capture prey in 60 per cent of the observations. The males tended to capture larger prey and use their hands. This suggests early humans were perhaps the first to fashion tools.

Sleep apnoea is a condition often typified by heavy snoring. It causes muscles in the airway to contract during sleep, usually resulting in a heavy snore. People with breathing problems while asleep are more likely to experience an early decline in memory and other brain functions. Researchers found that treating the problem with continuous positive airway pressure or CPAP saw significant results.

Astronomers are using a technique known as microlensing to find and characterise planets tens of thousands of light-years away. Most of the planets we know about are around 10-100 times closer than Ogle-2014-BLG-0124Lb. The gas giant is half as massive as Jupiter and could help astronomers gain a better understanding of the distribution of planets in the Milky Way.

Researchers found coffee can stop the growth of tumours in women who have already been treated with the drug tamoxifen. They looked more closely at two substances that usually occur in coffee – caffeine and caffeic acid. Caffeine caused breast cancer cells to divide less frequently and die more often, especially when it was drunk in combination with tamoxifen.

Robert Tomanovich, 55, has denied his actions are racist. He first hung a noose from a tree and a Confederate flag at his Michigan home. Scientists at Brandeis University in Massachusetts believe all-nighters to cram for an exam won't work because memory neurons that are responsible for converting short-term memories into long-term ones, work most effectively when a person is asleep. They focused their research on dorsal paired medial neurons, well-known memory consolidators in fruit flies. The mushroom body is where our memories are stored, and where, the scientists believe, the process takes place.

Avril Lavigne, 30, had Lyme disease, a bacterial infection passed to humans from a tiny tick bite. It is treatable with antibiotics, but can cause joint pain and inflammation, facial nerve palsies and even inflammation of the heart. If you have a health concern, always consult your own GP.

The Pentagon announced Tuesday it would exhume and try to identify the remains of some 400 sailors and Marines who died on the USS Oklahoma on December 7, 1941. The move is apparently part of a new policy on disinterring the remains of unknown troops. According to the new policy, bodies may be exhumed from Punchbowl or any other permanent American military cemeteries - but they cannot be removed from any other permanent American naval vessel.

Scientists studied neolithic ornaments to understand how farming spread. They looked at the adoption or rejection of ornaments linked to farmers. Farmers came to Europe 8,000 years ago and spread early agricultural practices. But Northern Europeans initially rejected the practice of farming, which was otherwise spreading throughout the rest of the continent.

Researchers from the Department of Twin Research analysed voting preferences of 2,355 twins born in the UK. They found that choosing who to vote for, or not, is strongly influenced by genetics. This suggests an underlying genetic influence is stronger than environmental or random factors.

Researchers in Spain say climate change impacted human migration. Hominins were able to branch out from Africa into Europe 1.4 million years ago. But as conditions warmed, they were able to inhabit the region with the help of tools. The theory is based on analysis of the Barranco León site in southeast Spain.

Researchers at Imperial College London examined Julius Caesar's symptoms. They say mini-strokes can explain better than epilepsy. Historians have long believed this was result of an epileptic attack. But new research suggests that the Roman general may in fact have been suffering from a series of mini-strokes that affected both his mental and physical state.

The men, named Jess Evans, Wylie Payne, Richard Phillips and Major Andrew Drum, set up an enormous cattle ranch there. In following years, as winters became harsher, the area became a town, with its own post office, grocery store and other buildings. Scientists say measurements made by the European space probe Philae, which landed on comet 67P in November, show the comet's core isn't magnetised. Some astrophysicists have suggested that magnetism might have been responsible for aligning and then binding together rocks into larger boulders. The findings credibly suggest other forces were responsible.

Scientists from Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School have developed a device that clips onto the camera of an iPhone 4S. Microbeads specifically target molecules that sit on the surface of cancerous cells. They say it can asses 100,000 cells from a single image in around 45 minutes. The researchers say they already tested the device to detect cervical cancer in tissue samples obtained during smear tests.

New study suggests that religious beliefs help people cope in inhospitable habitats. Societies with less access to food and water are more likely to believe in an all-powerful, deity. Researchers from the University of Wisconsin-Madison used historical, social, and ecological data to examine human behaviour. They found volunteers who had previously thought about death gave more money to a charity that said it would help people in the country.

SpaceX Dragon cargo ship arrived on the International Space Station last Friday. It carried 4,000 pounds of supplies, including a coffee machine. The espresso machine is three months late because of the backlog created by last year's launch explosion. Aside from the coffee machine, the Dragon also had in total 4,000 pounds of food, science research and other equipment. It will remain at the station until around 21 May, when it will be released full of experiments and discarded equipment for return to Earth.

Researchers at the University of Michigan looked at how a protein called a transcription factor, and two small stretches of DNA called enhancers, act as triggers for the Pomc gene. All three regulate how often and when the POMC cells use the gene to create the signal molecules that then go out to the body. When POMC neurons are absent, or not working properly, animals and humans grow dangerously obese.

Researchers at Stanford University examined the reaction of both primary and secondary school teachers in the United States to student race. They found teachers were more likely to view youngsters who they thought were black as troublemakers than those they thought were white. The findings may go someway towards explaining why black children are often disciplined more at schools compared to other pupils.

Scientists have found gas hydrates in the Arctic that are reservoirs for abiotic methane. Methane is 20 times more potent than carbon dioxide at trapping heat. The gas can escape through cracks and faults, and end up at the ocean floor. But in the Knipovich Ridge it is trapped as gas hydrate in the sediments.

West Pakistan Refugees are regarded as second class citizens in India's only Muslim-majority state. Most of the population never visited Pakistan, and live in the Jammu region. Scientists at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem studied octopuse movement. They found that orientation of its body and the crawling direction are controlled independently in the brain. Octopuses are thought to have evolved from clam-like creatures. But as they lost their hard protective shell, they seem to have evolved to move far faster than other members of the mollusc family like slugs or snails.

Knowing it's happened, it's like you are talking about someone else's kid' Police launched huge search operation using hashtag 'FindBecky' on February 19.
Paula McKay was told her daughter Natasha had suffered brain damage. She was delivered 10 weeks prematurely by C-section, but staff failed to ventilate her properly, which caused severe brain damage and cerebral palsy. When she became pregnant with her second child, less than two years later, Ms McKay returned to the same hospital. Staff assured her that the same mistakes would not be repeated.
Atlanta-based writer Alex Gray, 27, weighed 354lbs at his heaviest. He was inspired to make changes in his own life after seeing a friend who had a similar frame show off her fit new body at a Cinco De Mayo reunion. The writer said that he never tried drugs or alcohol because he was too tired to breathe heavily during one of their sexual encounters.
Researchers at the University of California, Berkeley studied dementia patients. They found that eating too much junk food caused brain shrinkage. Cognitive stimulation therapy is a tried and tested method to stimulate the brain.

Chancey Allen Luna, 17, allegedly killed the talented sportsman. The couple had returned from a trip to Australia just two days earlier. Prosecutors said 104 bullets were found in the car involved in the drive-by shooting.

Many owners can no longer afford to keep a horse, says one carer. The RSPCA alone took in 1,500 horses last year, many of them former family pets. Animal welfare charities are struggling to find a new home for the animals.

But Jeremy Kyle, who has raised Sarah, broke the news to Sarah's parents. He told Sarah: 'Whatever happens today she will still be my daughter. It will be the proudest day of my life if she is my dad'
Scientists from Ruhr-Universität Bochum analysed brain activity when a person smelled Hedione to find out how it changed their emotions and behaviour. They found that Hedione activated part of the hypothalamus - an area of the brain responsible for triggering the release of sex hormones in women. The results are compelling evidence that a pheromone effect different from normal olfactory perception indeed exists in humans, says scent researcher Prof Hanns Hatt.

Nick Woodman, 39, is set to be named the highest-paid CEO of 2014. He is the founder and CEO of GoPro, a camera which can be fixed to helmets, the body, equipment or a hand-held pole. The cameras are light, small and waterproof. They are used by professionals and hobbyists conquering 6ft waves.

ByHours.com allows users to book well-known London hotels in three-hour blocks. Users can pay for the time they use the room, and the hotel can resell it. The company has already signed up 25 hotels in London. It is now targeting other cities such as Berlin and Paris.

John Helinski, 62, lived in a cardboard box at a Tampa Bay bus stop for three years. He had all of his personal identification stolen so struggled to apply for a place at a homeless shelter. A cop and case manager then looked into his past, and found an old bank account with money and enough social security benefits in it to buy his own house. Helinski is now looking for a small apartment in Tampa Bay.

Owner Kevin O'Connor closed the shop for eight days after comments by him and his daughter, Crystal, to a local television station supporting a new religious objections law. The law, which has since been revised, sparked a boycott of Indiana.
Naomi Jacobs woke up in totally unrecognisable surroundings one morning. She had been struck with Transient Global Amnesia, a form of memory loss brought on by stress. The 'episodic' part of her memory shut down, meaning she had lost all her emotional memories. But after eight weeks, Miss Jacobs' memory began to return to normal.

Kyli Wolfson, 29, was diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis in October 2012. The condition causes inflammation of the pancreas and requires a surgical procedure to remove the pancreas from the body. After spending a year and a half abstaining from eating, Kyli was able to lose 80lbs.

Wildlife photographer Robert Fuller captured the fight on camera inside a 13ft-high elm tree stump in his garden. Barn owl attacked the pair with sharp talons and beaks as they tried to gain mastery of the box so they could lay eggs and rear their young. The kestrels found an alternative home for themselves and their mate, but the barn owl won.
Alice Dreger, a respected professor, attended a class on sex education at East Lansing High School earlier this week. She began tweeting horror stories about what happened to people who have had pre-marital sex. The teacher claimed that abstinence reduces pre-marital sex by one in six times. Now the school has banned her from the class for the entire lesson.

The next day Barner was still in pain and noticed that the tattoo started to puss and ooze around her left breast. She is now suing the parlor for reckless, careless and negligent behavior.
Michelle Knight appeared at the Cleveland Rape Crisis Center's Faces of Change Luncheon on Wednesday. Knight was chained inside Castro's house for almost 10 years - the longest of the three women who were kidnapped, imprisoned and abused by Ariel Castro. Knight did not reveal anymore about the man in her life, but said she feels comfortable sharing her story, because it can give others 'the same courage, hope and faith that I had' The luncheon raised a record $254,000 for the center, which counsels rape survivors.
The extraordinary black and white photos were taken between 1900 and 1911 during the Qing dynasty. They show landmarks almost devoid of visitors and no one had ever heard of a selfie. Some of the subjects in the photos offer an enchanting glimpse into China’s last imperial era, which ended in 1911.
